title: FGF5 Mutations and Inheritance of FT

Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Human hair grows in a cycle that includes a growth phase and a rest phase. A small fraction of the hairs on the scalp are in the rest phase, while the majority of the hairs on the scalp are in the growth phase, which allows the hair on the scalp to grow long. Conversely, the majority of hairs in areas such as the eyelashes are in the rest phase, which keeps those hairs short. Familial trichomegaly (<math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a genetic condition that results in excessively long eyelashes in affected individuals. In an investigation into the causes of <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a team of researchers identified mutations in the gene that codes for fibroblast growth factor-<math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that are associated with <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a protein that is secreted by certain cells and functions as a signaling molecule that influences the ratio of growth phase to rest phase in hair. The structure of the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene includes <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> exons and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> introns. Alternate splicing of the <math alttext="pre m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pre-mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed from the gene creates a long version of the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F G F 5 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a short version of the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F G F 5 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 1). Figure 1. A map of the splicing patterns that lead to the production of both the <math alttext="F G F 5 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5-L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein and the <math alttext="F G F 5 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Labels below the diagram refer to gene components for <math alttext="F G F 5 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and labels above the diagram refer to gene components for <math alttext="F G F 5 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Dotted lines indicate the portion(s) of the sequence that will be removed from the transcribed <math alttext="pre m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pre-mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to form either <math alttext="F G F 5 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="F G F 5 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . Researchers identified three different mutations in the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that have been associated with <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. These mutations, the positions of which are shown in Figure 1, include: • <math alttext="E 1 del T A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E1delTA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: a mutation in which a thymine and an adenine are deleted from Exon <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene• <math alttext="E 2 del G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E2delG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: a mutation in which a guanine is deleted from Exon <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene• <math alttext="E 3 sub T dash C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E3subT-C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: a mutation in which a thymine is substituted for a cytosine in Exon <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene The researchers collected data on a family with a history of <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and created a pedigree representing the instances of <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the family as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2. A pedigree representing five generations of a family with a history of <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The researchers analyzed the length of hairs from individuals with <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and from unaffected individuals and plotted the length of each hair as shown in Figure <math alttext="3 A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. They also determined the ratio of hairs in growth phase to hairs in rest phase as shown in Figure <math alttext="3 B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure <math alttext="3 A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Length of hairs taken from individuals with and without <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>Figure <math alttext="3 B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Proportion of hairs examined that were in growth phase compared with the proportion of examined hairs in rest phase In a final experiment, the researchers grew human hair in a petri dish with and without adding <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to the dish. The growth of the hair over an <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-day period was measured. The data from this experiment are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
